definition: Just coming into existence and beginning to show signs of development
example: The nascent industry soon grew into a major economic force.

definition: So small or unimportant as to be not worth considering
example: The cost increase was negligible.

definition: A newly coined word or expression
example: The tech world is full of neologisms.

definition: A person who is new to a subject or activity
example: As a neophyte at chess, he lost most games.
Her sarcastic remarks nettled him.

definition: A connection or series of connections
example: The university is a nexus for research collaborations.

definition: Having an extremely unpleasant smell; foul
example: The noisome garbage made the alley unbearable.
They charged a nominal fee for the service.
He gave a nonchalant shrug.
She stayed in a nondescript hotel.
Listening to old songs filled him with nostalgia.

definition: The state of being famous for something bad
example: He achieved notoriety for his reckless driving.

definition: New and unusual in an interesting way
example: She presented a novel approach to the problem.

definition: A slight difference in meaning, expression, or tone
example: He understood every nuance of her expression.

definition: To care for and encourage the growth or development of
example: Parents nurture their children's talents.

definition: Stubbornly refusing to change one's opinion or course of action

definition: To make something unclear or difficult to understand
example: The legal language only served to obfuscate the contract.

definition: Not aware of or concerned about what is happening around one
example: He was oblivious to the stares of others.
The meaning of the poem was obscure.

definition: Excessively eager to please or obey
example: He was followed by obsequious assistants.

definition: Out of date; no longer in use
example: Typewriters are now largely obsolete.

definition: Stubbornly refusing to change despite persuasion

definition: To remove a need or difficulty

definition: To block or stop up an opening or passage
example: A blood clot occluded the artery.
The odious smell filled the room.

definition: Assertive in a domineering way, especially about trivial matters
example: An officious security guard blocked the entrance.

definition: Giving the impression that something bad is going to happen
example: Dark clouds gave an ominous feeling.

definition: Having unlimited power; able to do anything
example: The king ruled with the belief he was omnipotent.

definition: A skilled and eloquent public speaker

definition: Conforming to traditional or established beliefs
example: The church follows orthodox teachings.

definition: Stated or appearing to be true, but possibly not so

definition: Characterized by vulgar or pretentious display

definition: Too elaborate or complicated in design

definition: To calm down anger or agitation; to bring peace

definition: Done with great care and thoroughness

definition: To make a disease or its symptoms less severe without removing the cause

definition: Pale, typically due to poor health

definition: Able to be touched or felt
So intense as to seem tangible

definition: A solution or remedy for all problems or diseases

definition: Widespread over a whole country or the world; prevalent

definition: An imitation for comic effect or ridicule

definition: Prejudiced in favor of a particular cause or group

definition: Relating to or consisting of money

definition: A person excessively concerned with minor details or rules

definition: Having an unemotional and stolidly calm disposition

definition: To be a sign or warning of something about to happen

definition: A sign or warning that something is likely to happen

definition: Cloudy, opaque, or thick with matter
example: The river water was turbid after the storm.

definition: Characterized by conflict, disorder, or confusion
example: They had a turbulent relationship.
The scandal was one of moral turpitude.
Smartphones have become ubiquitous.

definition: A final demand with a threat of consequences
example: They gave the rebels an ultimatum to surrender.
She took umbrage at his remarks.
He was unabashed about his beliefs.
The decision was unanimous among the members.
She is very talented but unassuming.

definition: Strange or mysterious in an unsettling way
example: He had an uncanny ability to predict events.
His uncouth behavior offended the guests.
Gossip can undermine trust.
She gave an unequivocal answer.
They enjoyed unfettered access to the data.
The tall boy was ungainly on the dance floor.

definition: Performed by or affecting only one side
example: They took unilateral action without consulting partners.

definition: Different from what is usual or traditional
example: She used an unorthodox teaching method.
The mission was an unprecedented success.
He escaped unscathed from the accident.

definition: Not able to be maintained or defended
example: The theory proved untenable.
They apologized for the untoward incident.
Her comment was an unwitting insult.
The coach upbraided the team for poor effort.
He came across as urbane and charming.

definition: To take power or position illegally or by force
example: The general usurped control of the government.

definition: Designed for usefulness rather than beauty
example: The building's design was purely utilitarian.

definition: An imagined perfect place or state
example: They dreamed of creating a utopia.

definition: To waver between different opinions or actions
example: She vacillated between two career options.

definition: Having or showing a lack of thought or intelligence
example: The movie was criticized for its vacuous dialogue.

definition: An unexpected and inexplicable change in a situation or behavior
example: They adapted quickly to the vagaries of the market.

definition: A person without a settled home or work, wandering from place to place
example: Police moved the vagrants out of the park.
His vainglorious speeches alienated voters.
She made a valiant effort to save the child.

definition: To check or prove the truth of something
example: The study validated the theory.

definition: Offering nothing stimulating or challenging; dull
example: The conversation was vapid and boring.

definition: The quality of being changeable or inconsistent
example: Weather variability is increasing with climate change.
The car veered off the road.

definition: Showing strong feeling; forceful and intense
example: He gave a vehement denial of the accusations.
The velocity of the car was 60 mph.

definition: Smooth, soft, and pleasant to touch or taste
example: The dessert had a velvety texture.

definition: A prolonged bitter quarrel or campaign against someone
example: He pursued a political vendetta against his rival.

definition: Accorded great respect due to age or dignity
example: The venerable professor retired after 50 years.
She was venerated as a saint.
He is known for his veracious testimony.

definition: In exactly the same words as were used originally
example: He repeated the instructions verbatim.

definition: Using more words than needed; wordy
example: The explanation was unnecessarily verbose.
The hills were verdant after the rainy season.
They were on the verge of a breakthrough.

definition: The appearance of being true or real
example: The novel lacked verisimilitude in its historical details.

definition: Used to emphasize the truthfulness of a description
example: The garden was a veritable paradise.

definition: Able to adapt or be adapted to many functions or activities
example: She is a versatile musician.

definition: A trace or remnant of something no longer existing
example: No vestige of the castle remains.

definition: To make someone feel annoyed or worried
example: The delays vexed passengers.
They discussed a viable solution to the problem.
The feast offered various delicious viands.
The market was vibrant with colors.

definition: Experienced through the feelings or actions of another
example: She lived vicariously through her children.

definition: A change of circumstances, typically unwelcome
example: They endured the vicissitudes of war.
Security guards must remain vigilant.

definition: To speak or write about someone in an abusively disparaging manner
example: The press vilified the politician.

definition: To clear from blame or suspicion
example: The new evidence vindicated her.

definition: Having a strong desire for revenge
example: His vindictive streak made him a poor leader.

definition: A person highly skilled in music or another art
example: She’s a piano virtuoso.
The virulent disease spread rapidly.
Honey is more viscous than water.

definition: Thinking about or planning the future with imagination
example: He is a visionary entrepreneur.
Oxygen is vital for life.
The review was vitriolic.
She was a vivacious hostess.
There was vociferous opposition to the plan.
The stock market can be volatile.

definition: The power of using one's will
example: She left of her own volition.

definition: Speaking or spoken fluently and at length
example: He was voluble about his new project.

definition: Having an eager approach to an activity
example: A voracious reader finishes books quickly.

definition: A mass of swirling fluid or air
example: A water vortex formed near the drain.

definition: To decrease in power or size
example: Her influence began to wane.
Be wary of strangers.
She wavered between two job offers.
The teacher struggled with the wayward student.
He was weary after the long journey.
The preview whetted my appetite for the film.
The whimsical decor delighted visitors.

definition: Skilled at gaining an advantage, often deceitfully
example: The wily fox evaded the trap.

definition: Having a feeling of vague or regretful longing
example: She looked wistfully out the window.
His witty banter kept the audience entertained.
The tale is full of woe.

definition: Accustomed or used to doing something
example: He spoke in his wont manner.
He faced the wrath of the public.

definition: In a very unhappy or unfortunate state
example: The refugees lived in wretched conditions.
She gave him a wry smile.

definition: Dislike or prejudice against people from other countries
example: The law was criticized for promoting xenophobia.

definition: To have an intense longing for something
example: He yearned for his hometown.
The farm yields good crops each year.
They yoked the oxen to the plow.
In days of yore, knights roamed the land.

definition: Showing great energy or enthusiasm for a cause
example: The campaign was led by zealous volunteers.
The empire reached its zenith under his rule.
A warm zephyr blew through the meadow.

definition: The outer peel of citrus fruit for flavoring
example: She tackled the project with zest.

definition: To move forward by taking sharp turns alternately left and right
example: The path zigzags up the hill.
I know zilch about that subject.

definition: A bluish-white metal used in alloys and for galvanizing
example: Zinc is essential for good health.

definition: A belt of the heavens divided into twelve astrological signs
example: Her zodiac sign is Leo.

definition: An area or stretch of land having particular characteristics
example: This is a no-parking zone.

definition: To move or travel very quickly
example: The car zoomed past us.
